Name: -1_the_to_and_of
Representative_Docs:
["Honestly, the apocalyptic talk about Republicans' generational prospects is ridiculous.

There will always be cross pressure between the fact that people want as much for themselves as possible.

The real reason millennials are so left leaning is as simple as it is glaring - the GOP positions on basically anything don't offer a damn thing to them.

Student loans? Climate? Even tax cuts for people that are disproportionately likely to be in their circumstances?

Nothing.

All the GOP has to do is nominate their own version of Bill Clinton and moderate on a handful of things and they'd be fine 

But they haven't demonstrated any interest in doing so.

Every 40 years or so, there is a political shift generationally as the policies promoted by the incumbent political reality become irrelevant and useless to the younger ones.

Hoover gave way to FDR, Carter gave way to Reagan, Bush and Trump to Obama/Biden and whoever else.

There is no reason to believe the GOP can't win today if it moderates a bit nor is there any reason to believe there won't be another right turn in 40 years now.", '100% convinced he wants to run in 2020, realized he couldnt win this time and just doing it for the free press, increasing his name recognition and the free food.

He is counting on Trump losing so horribly bad in the GE that voters will go towards the middle. Plus, who is going to run again in 2020? Ryan will have a lot of baggage after his years as speaker and Hailey isnt that much of a candidate.

I mean, did somebody knew who John Kasich was before febraury? 

The man has been a competent politician his whole life winning really tough races more than once. in 2011 he was the most unpopular governor of the country and in 2014 he got re-elected with 2/3 of the vote. Do you really believe Kasich has been unable to raise more funds than Christie or Walker that dropped out months ago?

I am convinced that every thing he has done on the last 2 months was to position himself to be the 2020 frontrunner.

I mean, he needs two things. The first one is that Trump wins the nomination. The second one is that he gets destroyed by HRC.

I mean he could be having a little hope to be chosen by the convention but he would have a much better shot at winning the GE at 2020 than now.
', 'Couple of things to note, here: 

One: The margin it passed by in congress is relatively meaningless. This was a strategic vote, done so in a way to protect as many vulnerable Republicans as possible. Note that there are way more congressmen that voted against the AHCA that are in competitive districts than aren't. Many of these districts even voted for Clinton in 2016. They're protecting their seats and nothing more. It wouldn't have gone up for a vote if the GOP knew they didn't have the votes for it in the first place, which is exactly why the initial bill prior to the amendments did not.

Two: The senate might make major changes... they might not. That is yet to be seen. But more amendments (or a completely different plan entirely) doesn't mean that this legislation is dead. 

It's May. We've got a lonnnnng ways to go in the 115th session. Remember that the ACA wasn't passed until about this time in the second year of the 111th. There is still plenty of time for back and forth on healthcare. 

Lastly, I don't think the the House is going to be as resistant to more moderate changes as people are saying. Legislators now have their names tied to this- Freedom Caucus members don't want to have to go back to their constituents in 5 months and explain to them why they refused to pass the "Obamacare Repeal" bill. Some might fight it, but going by the current "nay" votes, there are way more moderates to be won than there are hardcore conservatives to lose.']

Name: 0_the_to_and_they
Representative_Docs:
["I'm a Democrat but there's some Republicans I like.  
  
One could say there's an issue I'm a single issue voter on, and that's on politicians that show an interest in governing.  Being open to debate, presenting a case to the voters, and knowing the process.  Those things matter to me.  Trump never did any of that, and while I didn't vote for Romney, I did vote for Bush, and there are Republicans that I would give a fair hearing to right now.  
  
But anyone in the Tea Party/MAGA camp I just can't listen to, because they have absolutely zero interest in actually fulfilling the role they're elected to.  Someone like Hillary, who is certainly controversial, if nothing else, actually is interested in policy and governing and I think that makes her worth considering even when you disagree on the policy, because the alternative is to vote against a continuance of government (assuming of course, the other person/party simply has zero interest in governing)", "> reorient voters priorities

See this right here...this is the real reason why they will fail.

Our elected representatives are supposed to represent us. They're not supposed to set priorities for voters, they're supposed to find out what their voters want them to prioritize and then address those issues.

It couldn't be more clear by even June of last year that the January 6th stuff was not what voters cared about. The far left cared about massive expansions of government and seeing as they didn't get that they are pissy. They lost moderates when they messed up bipartisanship, the Afghan exit and the economy. The right despises every bit of their virtue signaling social agenda so that wasn't going to win them any votes there.

I have never seen a political party so absolutely rudderless. Everything they have done in the past year and a half has turned to utter shit. Biden now polls worse than Trump. 

They are pivoting to the January 6th stuff because they literally have nothing else. How someone blew all of their political capital one year in and burned all bridges and now can only say 'well at least I'm not Trump' is absolutely unbelievable. Biden is on track to go down as one of the most incompetent presidents ever.

Honestly he should be glad Russia attacked Ukraine, it seems to be the only thing people think he's doing well enough at. Everything else is garbage.", "But what about checks and balances? Also voters just expecting to vote for someone that will be able to perfectly enact all of their policy proposals is unreasonable and unrealistic politicians aren't any less likely to lie in a parliamentary system and having the executive branch effectively have oversight over the legislative branch creates a massive problem with conflict of interest

The other thing is lots of times to be quite frank the voters don't even know what they want because in every pole there's consistently a large majority of people that want to simultaneously lower taxes increase spending and balance the budget and it's kind of obvious you can do two out of three but not all three and any political system in which the population is an educated enough to understand that fact we'll have the problems our system is regardless of whether it's parliamentary or presidential

With all that said I wouldn't be opposed to a state trying it as it could be a useful experiment in democracy but to me the far more important issue is getting rid of first-past-the-post so we could actually have a true multi-party democracy where you don't vote for the lesser of two evils"]

Name: 1_he_his_trump_him
Representative_Docs:
['No. Despite the bad news, the Republican establishment still want his voters. But his voters are loyal to Trump, even with all the indictments and Trump pledging to run from a jail cell. So, because of this, Trump still has all the power. And even if the Republican establishment got their wish and he decided to no longer seek the GOP nomination, he could very easily go third party overnight with the aim of creating a schism in the Republican Party. Libertarian Party could take him in. The People’s Party could take him in, as they’d gain nationwide ballot access faster with him than other candidates.  He could resurrect the Reform Party. He could even start his own party from the ground up. 

Don’t forget there’s still an audience out there that is desperate for a strong third-party candidate. I would not be surprised if some of them are desperate enough for such a candidate that they’d tolerate Trump. Trump just knows how to continually live rent free in other people’s heads.', 'I always argue that Trump could have very well won *if he had just shut the hell up and let the experts work during the pandemic.* If he had just let them do their things he could have easily cinched a 2020 win and we would have seen him in a second term. It was even the best setup because his administration approved sending stimulus checks to everyone. It could have been an easy win-win.

But no, he had to put the attention on himself at all times. He had to keep contradicting his experts because he wanted to make sure he was the one telling people what to do. He had to make it all about himself.', 'IMO Trump’s goal is not to be president again, at least that is not the direct goal. He does not want to finish what started. He does not want to help Americans. He wants to undo his loss in 2020, which will result in him being president again.

He cannot accept that he lost in 2020. His ego does not allow it. He has to stay who he is, otherwise victory will just be victory, not an undoing of his loss.

It’s quite literally the definition of insanity. Trump wants to do the same thing he did in 2016 and in 2020, but expects a different result. He wants to be himself. He does not want to adapt. He wants to bludgeon the country into submission to him, not adapt to suit the political climate.

Trump is built on the notion that his instincts are always right, that he does not need to learn or adapt or rethink. He cannot abandon that.']

Name: 2_the_to_it_that
Representative_Docs:
["> high tax brackets (over $1 million per year, for example) pay a higher tax rate?

Well first off, there isn't such a tax bracket. The highest single filing is around $500k.

Secondly, most people making that kind of money are getting it in the form of stocks, which means now we are dealing with Capital Gains taxes not Income taxes, which messing with that has negative impacts on retirees, general investment flow, as well as other unforeseen consequences. 

The other problem is that typically DEM policies say they want to target Millionaires, but they typically always end up also hitting the brackets that go from $85k-200k, in order to generate the needed revenue for their big projects/plans. These are typically the tax brackets that always get screwed over every time there's a policy change in the other direction, which is where the bulk of your middle class income resides and that range typically always has the cut off for any kind of benefit. Just look at the stimulus cut offs.", "Yeah, I'd argue its low wages, not the stimulus. Companies have been complaining about not having enough workers since 2013 or so. The companies doing the complaining are low wage jobs like service jobs, retail and logistics. I guarantee if they raised wages they could get more workers in no problem. The thing is, companies don't wanna do that because it means those at the very top would have a little less in the short term even though its been shown keeping high wages is good for a company in the long term as it keeps turn over low. People who got layed off from their low wage job have had time away from it to realize how unfairly they were being treated and either look for better work or maybe even go back to school. Maybe the goal should not be to create a world where people need to work a dead end, low paying job to survive, but to make one where companies actually have to compete for workers by offering quality wages and benefits.", 'When the Fair Labor Standards Act, which established the first minimum wage in the US, passed in 1938 FDR famously said: 

>"In my Inaugural I laid down the simple proposition that nobody is going to starve in this country. It seems to me to be equally plain that no business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country.

>By business I mean the whole of commerce as well as the whole of industry; by workers I mean all workers, the white collar class as well as the men in overalls; and by living wages I mean more than a bare subsistence level-I mean the wages of decent living."

A job not paying enough to make an honest living off of is not a natural consequence of capitalism, and indeed if you read John Adams and other original theorists they would be aghast at the idea of something like wage slavery. The current situation is the result of conscious decisions and the conscious exercise of political power by the wealthy to protect their interests. If you getting a hamburger in two minutes from your car is important enough to pay someone to do, it's important enough to pay them a living wage to do it. Even if they're a kid. Even if they're living with parents. Even if they have roommates. Your right to save less than a dollar on consumer goods is not greater than the right of employees to food and shelter.']

Name: 3_he_the_trump_to
Representative_Docs:
["Apparently the search has to do with 15 boxes of classified documents that he took with him when he left office.  I think this story has been flying under the radar (this is the first I've heard of it), but it's been developing since at least February apparently.  

Good news for trump haters, this case should be pretty cut and dry.  Did he have those documents? Yes.  Was he supposed to? No.  A quick Google tells me that this is punishable by up to five years jail time, but I wouldn't hold my breath for that.  

This case has no direct link to Jan 6, but any evidence that they just seized can absolutely be used in that case if relevant.", 'There is no legitimate claim that this is politicizing justice. That is just an attempt to give Trump cover. 

Trump had 5 years to learn the rules around classified data. He acted like he was an expert when he talked about locking Hillary Clinton up. So that makes him taking them at all unacceptable. 

Then, when the archivists ask for them back, he ignores them. They subpoena, he gives them half of it. They continue discussions and send formal rehear letters, which he ignores. They took every step to do this low key, and Trump obstructed. 

Even when they did execute a warrant, they did it early morning, and when Trump wasn’t there. They made it as low key as possible, until Trump started sending out messages. 

If someone wanted to politicize this, they would not have given so many opportunities to keep it relatively quiet. He literally broke a law that he specifically increased penalties for. He made his own actions a felony. This is just what justice looks like, and politics doesn’t play a part. 

I think people need to look at how disingenuous the argument from the right is, and I hope it changes their perspective.', 'This warrant was very strict in what they had to prove to obtain it. You need to specify the crime, the exact evidence you are looking for, and prove that the evidence is currently where you want to raid. Do you genuinely think that somehow the FBI fabricated all of that, that not a single conservative FBI agent noticed, and that Trump appointee Christopher Wray signed off on it all? Law enforcement lies but not nearly like this. It would be an entirely new kind of lie for them to tell and somehow a giant network of them would have had to pull this off in secret on their first try. 

That is so much less likely than Trump having especially sensitive documents among the 15 boxes of classified documents he himself has said he has had for months.']

Name: 5_russia_ukraine_nato_putin

["Europe is absolutely fine with that, and in fact most of Europe is part of NATO right now.   They aren't fine with Russia trying to reestablish it's post-collapse borders and dominate Eastern Europe like it did for 50 years.    That's the path to WWIII.   Europe will not allow that.  


And what's quite clear is that Russia is the worst corrupt regime in Europe.  The oligarchs have been stealing everything that isn't nailed down for decades now.  That's why the Russian military is so underprepared and so many of it's weapon systems are mirages.   This is how Putin came to power and was fine with it until it hurt his empire building - now he's having the people who have done these things murdered, not the least of which were the head of their largest tank manufacturer and their aerospace complex.

This both sides nonsense is ridiculous.   There'd be no war in Ukraine if Russia wasn't invading.   Saying that we should force peace so Russia gets to keep it's ill gotten gains now that they aren't winning is just supporting militarism and fascism.", 'I think it is extremely unlikely that there will be even a limited strike against military targets unless the Russian strike looks intentional.  I ***highly*** doubt that the strike was intentional.  A single small strike against Poland that achieves literally no objective other than giving NATO a casus belli to enter the war is such a stupid idea that not even the Russians dumb as dirt commanders would float the idea.

Russia's goals in Ukraine have changed over time as Ukraine has denied them one objective after another.  One goal that has been absolutely consistent for Russia though is to, whatever they do, not get NATO involved.  In fact, keeping NATO from getting involved is the absolute highest priority for the completely obvious reason that Russia's military would be destroyed if NATO joined, and their only recourse would be nukes.

NATO "escalation" for this incident will be NATO supplying Ukraine with more weapons of the type that they want.  NATO might use this as an excuse to hand over some weapons that they had previously holding back on, but that's pretty much the extent of the retaliation I'd expect.', "I doubt even that would have been enough for Putin. Ukraine would still be creating closer economic ties with the west, even if it was prevented from joining the EU. It would still develop into a competitor to Russia in the sale of oil and gas, and given that they also charge Russia for pipelines through their country it could undercut at least a part of their supply at will. It would still be able to toss out any leader that is too pro-Russia like it did in 2014 and throw out any agreement with Russia they made as well. It would still control the water supply to Crimea as long as it controlled the territory between Crimea and the Dniper river. It would still cut Crimea off from Russia by land leaving only a single bridge that could be destroyed as Crimea's sole connection to Russia.

Russia isn't going to stop until it can control these things or make them irrelevant. I guarantee that Putin will not stop this war until they control at least everything between Russia and Crimea, as well as everything between Crimea and the Dnieper in the south. I also expect that they want to take the rest of the coastline of Ukraine to further deprive them of Black Sea oil and gas fields as well as establish a Russian border with Transnistria, but Russia isn't doing so well militarily already and a siege of Odessa might have fallen out of favor by now."]

Name: 6_state_the_states_of
Representative_Docs:
['I would say, if you are gonna move, try and move to a place where you can better influence the vote. Either a more purple or light blue district, or if you are in Georgia, to another purple or light blue state. I don’t blame people for leaving red states, but we cannot keep ceding grounds in purple states. And look if you must leave, I get it, especially if you are in MTG country. But I think many people don’t realize that blue states have crazy red parts and we are not gonna win by continuing to concentrate around 10 or so cities. And leaving crazy folks in charge of the US is not gonna be any better no matter where in the world you may run. It’s a hard truth, but I think we need to start making plans to move and take back the senate and House instead of leaving and letting the US potentially be controlled by people with nothing apparently holding them back.', 'It is true that gerrymandering is rampant, especially so in Red states. In my state of SC, for instance, Democrats reliably garner over 40% of the vote in Senate and presidential elections, but can really only compete for one house district out of eight. 

If a non-partisan, technocratic route was possible, that would be an improvement. There are some good proposals for this, especially in some of the blue states. 

I still believe the larger problem is the unrepresentative measures built into American federalism. We have a deeply flawed democracy when a minority can consistently win control of government because of just how much outsized representation outsized rural states get, while DC and PR are not given representation for reasons that probably have more to do with sheer partisan advantage and racism than anything else.', "Um, it's both? The population can usually have some amount of range but it has to fall within certain parameters. It changes as the population of the country changes, that's what the census is for. Each state is different but a lot of the states I have the districts drawn by the state legislature every 10 years. This usually leads them to brought themselves as many districts as possible, they find out which people don't support them and then they draw the districts around them. The goal being to put as many of your opponents into a district as possible. However, you're also not allowed to break up certain protected districts, particularly racial districts. If you have a large enough minority population you're supposed to get some level of fair representation under the Voting Rights Act, but the Republican courts don't always enforce it very well, especially since, with the exception of a few big headline cases, the Supreme Court has become almost exponentially more right-wing over the last 20 years, and it was only getting more right-wing before that. Increased polarization and politicization hasn't helped."]

Name: 8_trans_gay_that_is
Representative_Docs:
['That doesn't provide reason to ban gender affirming care. "We don't really know" ends up being an argument that cannot be proven false and is repeated indefinitely with moved goalposts. When transitioning and gender affirming care saves lives, it is cruel and unreasonable to cut off people who seek it and are already receiving it.

Here's a funny thing: so many of the trans people who did transition after 2016 did so then not because they applied and were rejected, but because they didn't know they could get gender affirming care or that their feelings were gender dysphoria. "Ah, all people dream of being the opposite sex!" "Most of them don't" "wait what" *egg cracking noises. later:* "Oh, THAT was dysphoria?"  


I started transitioning in 2018/2019, but it's not like my dysphoria just cropped up around that time. I looked back over the 26 years I had lived, and realized I had been feeling dysphoria since a young age, and especially since puberty. Why didn't I transition in my teen years? Because even though I hated being a guy and thought girls had to so much better, I didn't think hormone replacement therapy could make me pass as a woman. It does (along with voice training and other things I've done). Heck, I remember therapists, friends, and even a teacher or two asking me if I was trans; I denied it because deep down I feared I couldn't pass.', 'I still don’t think that logic holds when you’re talking about tolerating or accepting gay people. All gay people want is to be left alone, that’s tolerance and acceptance. Nobody would be trying to make this distinction if we were talking about race, you’d just be called a racist if you said you didn’t think seeing black people was acceptable. Being gay is more equivalent to that than having a certain fetish.

Gay people being in movies is representation, it being discussed in schools is just to tell people that they exist and educate them on the struggles they’ve faced. Nobody ever killed anyone for wanting to be choked during sex. Pride Month exists for gay people to celebrate who they are because for so long just existing could get them killed or worse.

Saying you don’t want to see that stuff is adjacent to denying reality because you don’t like it.', 'This is a lot of text to say "it's not fair that people are calling the right bigoted for doing bigoted things."

Sorry, I don't buy what you're selling. Like this:

"Once again Republicans used evidence and common sense involving the protection of kids."

Is just you lying. Common sense and evidence would support allowing doctors, parents, and kids to make decisions regarding their healthcare, not banning it. 

You are whining about "dragging kids into it" while ignoring that most puberty blockers, most gender affirming surgeries, most gender affirming care, is given to **cisgender** kids. You are defending the criminalization of behavior that is fine for one class (cisgender) and not for another (trans). 

Your view is not reasonable or moderate, it's bought into a a long line of untrue propaganda that you are uncritically spreading here.

>The drag show thing is weird, I will have to look into it. That could be something the GOP is on the wrong side of.

That you are unaware of this is a demonstration of your ignorance on these issues and how the right is treating them. Maybe you should actually learn something about this before you accuse the left of hysteria. We aren't the ones passing unconstitutional laws banning behavior.']

Name: 9_gun_guns_to_the
Representative_Docs:
['They could flat out pivot from “some/all guns are bad” to “guns are bad in the wrong hands.” Of course that is more difficult constitutionally, and ripe for “first they came for…” type arguments. But seriously domestic abusers with a revolver seems worse to me than a responsible owner with an AR-15. I think at some point the US ought to be able to say, “naw, you aren’t in my militia. We will do without your help.”

I’m pro-gun, but when someone tells me we can’t do anything about school shootings because of 2A protections then I find myself in an anti-2A position. Because if it stands in the way of sane regulation it’s a problem even if I think the majority of people ought to have access to guns if they want.

And I’m done hearing about standing up to the tyranny of the government because all that really means is brandishing guns at civil servants and protesters seeking political change. None of those lawn chair warriors are taking on armed government officers when they show up trampling on people. No one is defending people from being flat out murdered by police. Those people can go back to jerking off with gun oil because they aren’t fighting for freedom or justice or anything at all, really, other than the right to have guns.', "You missed the point there. Democrats don't establish real gun control laws that would take away guns. They just create shitty feel good laws that don't have any real affect on guns. Banning certain guns just because they look scary is not effective gun control.

If and when the US is willing to give up the second amendment, they can push for abolishing guns, but until then, it's a waste of time.", 'Disclaimer: I support gun control, hate gun culture and everything it represents, including libertarianism, toxic masculinity, hyper-individualism, and jingoistic nationalism.

However, I have to note that strong polling support for gun control over gun proliferation may not matter. It will always be politically easier to side with gun proliferation than gun control. Almost nobody who supports gun control will be willing to change their vote based on this one issue, while a non-insignificant number of gun supporters will change their vote based on this issue. "They're coming to take our guns" political ads are played for this reason. 538 has noted this effect, and called gun control support "broad but shallow", while gun proliferation support "narrow but deep".

For gun control supporters, their idea is a set of data, numbers, and context about what policy is better, and fairly abstract at that. They don't think about it too much in their daily lives. For gun proliferation supporters, however, a gun is a physical thing that they can hold in their hands, and the image of someone taking it away is a powerful political message that cannot be defeated by any stats that show Australians are much less likely to die from guns than Americans.

I am curious to see if any gun proliferation supporters will agree with this analysis.']

Name: 23_the_constitution_of_amendment
Representative_Docs:
['> The U.S. Constitution has been amended 27 times, an average of once every 8.6 years.

While technically true, this is a deceptive statement. The first 10 amendments were written almost immediately after the Constitution was ratified. So more like every 13.6 years for the final 17. But still, that is deceptive, because the amendments came in clusters.

The last amendment was done in 1992, **30 years ago**, but was a semi-stunt, having been proposed in 1789, ratified by 7 states right out of the gate, one more in 1873, and then the rest in 1978-1992. 

The 26th Amendment was done in 1971, **51 years ago**. This lowered the voting age to 18, and was spurred by the fact that 18-year olds were being drafted and sent to Vietnam.

The 25th Amendment was done in 1967, **55 years ago**. This handled presidential succession, and was spurred by JFKs assassination.

The 24th Amendment was done in 1964, **58 years ago**. This prevented poll taxes, and was done in response to the Civil Rights crisis of the mid-60s.

The 23rd Amendment was done in 1961, **61 years ago**. it gave people living in Washington DC the right to vote in presidential elections, a significant oversight, but ostensibly also a civil-rights issue, since over half the city was black.

Since the 27th Amendment was originally proposed in 1789, putting it aside, it has been over 50 years since a constitutional amendment has been proposed. This is a much more dramatic number than the 8.6 "average".', "I would argue that they are actually arguing for the latter option as this is usually a comment made in response to why an institution holds anti-popular stances.  

Also because option 1 is tautologically impossible.  It would require redistributing the population across the 50 states which neither the people nor the states want to happen. That is the *only* way that the representation would again be reflective of the actual population over the long term. A short term consensus could form in the event that the populous and the less populous states just *happened* to agree on a bunch of things, but if they ever started to diverge there would again be no built in way of reining in a tyranny of the minority. 

IMO because of this, people who say “well this is a republic of *states*, not *people*” are just daring history to have the federal government in DC overthrown in favor of a more representative government.

Edit: Those who make peaceful change impossible make violent Revolution inevitable.

I should probably be clearer in that I am not *pushing* for a revolution of that kind, but rather simply to say that historically speaking this kind of thing does not remain out of whack for long.  If people value the constitution then they need to work to change it so that the US government better represents it's entire population rather than just it's 50 polygons on a sphere.  If we don't then it *will* be changed, only *without* their input, given time.", '>The constitution itself was based on broad agreement and debated throughout the country. If we had anything like that level of national agreement, you'd be right. But we don't. We must use the constitutional means of amendment, or all is lost (literal fighting).

Yeah, I'm done with tyranny of the minority. I don't respect the "rule of law" because in this case, the rule is absolutely fucked and being weaponized by a propaganda-poisoned minority.

>As such, both tribes must come to a realization that they must genuinely engage with the views of the other. 

No.

>Nobody can rip any other view "out from the root" and think this can be done in a peaceful manner. 

This SCOTUS court and Seante BSery is pushing us closer and closer to a non-peaceful resolution.

>We are stuck with each other in our mutual discontents. Not a pleasant reality, but reality nonetheless.

No. We have a moral duty to not follow unjust law and break systems of disenfranchisement and oppression.

>>That whenever any form of government becomes destructive to these ends,\xa0it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it

Note how it says it is the right of ***the people***, not a right of the states or a right of 3/4 of the states? Our written rule of law is trumped by the right of ***the people*** to remake their government if it isn't doing it's job.']

Name: 24_healthcare_insurance_health_to
Representative_Docs:
['Regarding healthcare expenses, the US spends more per capita than any other industrialized country - all of which all have some form of universal healthcare. Granted, those all look pretty different in how they do that. But the reality is that Americans are paying for each other’s healthcare already. That’s exactly what insurance is. The question is, do we want to keep paying for it this way? Or another, more cost efficient way, where everyone gets access?', "So, To pay for it would be a 6 or 7 percent Payroll Tax for all Employees 

But, Private Insurance represents 58% of US Adults.  The [typical person](https://www.healthsystemtracker.org/household-health-spending-calculator/?_sft_hhsc_insurance=employer&_sft_hhsc_size=single&_sft_hhsc_income=average&_sft_hhsc_health=average-health) with employer coverage, spends 3% - 6% of their income on health insurance and Out of Pocket Costs

So those paying 3 or 4 or 5 percent would see a higher costs

-----
Then, add in 70 million Americans get free healthcare from a Socialized Single Payer Program of Medicaid

* Medicaid has very low costs to enrollees as few place are allowed to bill out of pocket and Costs are from State Budgets with no single tax attached.  

That's 70 million people paying more

-----
But of course not everyone has insurance, 27.5 million, did not have health insurance at any point during the year

   * There are 5.1 million people that make over $100,000 that are uninsured.
   * There are 9.1 million people that make $50,000 - $100,000 that are uninsured
   * There are around 4.5 million people who were uninsured in 2018 and making between $25,000 - $50,000 and could not afford insurance or qualify for Medicaid as the most common reason for uninsured  

So that's ~100 million people paying 0 for healthcare, and 155 Million people on Private Insurance with Most of them in a 3-6 percent of income expenses.", ">There are so many reasons why a state cannot do universal healthcare. **They don’t have control of the regulations** and they don’t have any mechanism for handling people who move to the states for healthcare that will survive a court challenge plus they don’t have a guarantee that the federal government will give them back all the healthcare dollars under its control.

This is key. Single-payer is essential to health care reform, but it's not a silver bullet. It would largely reduce administrative costs and free up money that would otherwise just be profit for insurance companies, but actual cost of care will still be high if we aren't also reforming the hospital system and the drug market. That decidedly takes national action."]

Name: 28_impeachment_impeached_the_to

['I think it's been shown nowadays that impeachments don't really mean anything if the senate doesn't follow through. The impeachment of Trump kind of means nothing more than a footnote that a bunch of democratic reps thought he met the criteria for impeachment.

Name: 30_filibuster_the_to_senate
Representative_Docs:
['> The filibuster was used in the first session of the senate. But then there was no way to stop the filibuster.

That's not true. The Senate had the "previous question" rule to limit debate.

> The filibuster that is brought up today as being added to the senate rules, was don't to allow the blockage, unless a super majority against it existed.


I'm not sure what this means.', 'And this ‘power” you’re referring to is implementing the policies that the populace appointed you to fulfil? And um..  why not? That’s how every state without a filibuster, how every other democracy on the planet, and how THIS country operated BEFORE the senate made up the filibuster by accident (which means it IS a big, and not a feature).

Think of it this way. If the filibuster was removed today and the gop somehow ended up with a trifecta and they said “alright guys so we’re banning abortions everywhere, defunding social security education and healthcare, gay people can’t get married anymore and trans people can’t transition” what exactly do you think their chances are of keeping that trifecta in that next election or gaining one in any foreseeable future? 

See, that’s called being held accountable by your constituents. It’s why the ACA repeal failed and it’s why despite all this “letting the parties legislate with no filibuster will just cause them to undo everything from eachother and we’ll descend to chaos!” Bs, this never actually occurs at LL In literally every other country in the world and a large chunk of our states without filibuster.

At the end of the day, this argument is nothing but “I don’t want to do what most people want to do so I should have the right to stop them because I prefer what I want” and nothing else.', 'Can we bring back the actual filibuster?

If someone wants to filibuster, they have to actually stand in the senate chamber and speak, they can hand off to another Senator, but if no Senator is available to keep filibustering, then a vote is called.  Note, filibusters are 24/7 events.

It forces people to mean it when they filibuster, and will make sure that the entire nation will focus on the subject of the filibuster, which can make one side really uncomfortable based on how the public feels about the subject.

Filibuster a bill to rebuild US infrastructure, you slowly lose support for the filibuster. Filibuster a bill to make abortion illegal, 70% of the country starts yelling at the party trying to pass the law snd a lot of women vote in the next election.

Heck, if the public supports your position, doing an actual filibuster will help your cause.  Handing the Senate majority leader a piece of paper saying "we are filibustering X" and having the Senate vote to allow it is silly.']

Name: 31_mccarthy_to_he_speaker
Representative_Docs:
["Yeah. Sure, Dems lost the House, and that obviously sucks, but the make-up of this Congress is a great consolation prize.

McCarthy is screwed either way. If he wants the nuts on board, he'll need to give concessions, and a lot of the stuff they're asking for is... uh, not great for him, to say the least. They want every member to be able to call a Motion to Vacate vote literally whenever (so his job is never safe and the House can vote to get rid of him whenever he makes Gaetz or MTG or Biggs upset), they want committee members to vote for their chairmen (so he can't put his own people at the helm), they want to make it easier for bills to be brought to the floor (so leadership can't block objectively bad, nutty votes), etc.

And if he gives in to the crazies, he's alienating the moderates, giving them even more incentive to work with Dems. I really don't wanna be too bullish on this because this kind of dissent usually dies down before January, but even if McCarthy wins on the first ballot, there's a semi-realistic scenario where Jeffries is, for all intents and purposes, Shadow Speaker thanks to the Biden 16 and McCarthy selling his soul to the HFC.", "Don't forget that the House is holding together by a thread. The speaker vote made them into a laughingstock, especially on the penultimate, when they were talking about how great McCarthy was and how he knew the caucus well and the chaos was actually Democracy at work and McCarthy preemptively celebrated on Instagram... And then it failed. Huge egg on the face moment. 

Those deals with the devil might be coming back to haunt McCarthy too. According to reports, his own leadership team is in chaos. It increasingly looks like they might not even have a budget proposal because they can't agree on one. McCarthy is already publicly blaming one of the other Republicans, which is atypical for him. 

We may very well see more speaker votes soon.", "To be fair, I think this threat is a little overblown, which is why McCarthy agreed to it.  It has a high potential to continue to embarrass McCarthy, but I think a low potential to actually remove him.

Any one member can initiate a motion to vacate, and they wouldn't need any support, and they have rules which would force the house to take it up.  But then it still goes to a vote of the full house, which means they'd still need 5 members to align with all democrats to remove McCarthy, and then start another floor fight for a new speaker with no real consensus.  

Short of a new GOP darling stepping up to steal the speakership from McCarthy with the backing of both the fringe right and all democrats, this is a fairly empty threat.  

But it means any one member can call out McCarthy on the floor, any day that congress is in session, and very publicly say you're not doing the job and we're going to make everyone vote on it.

This is exactly what happened to Boehner.  The Tea Party wanted him out, and the democrats firmly said they're not interested in helping because whoever replaced him would be even less desirable.  But Boehner took it as a critical condemnation of his performance and later stepped down anyway.  I don't think McCarthy has even that much dignity, and would never walk away no matter how humiliated he is."]
